5#ifndef V8_OBJECTS_TRUSTED_OBJECT_H_
6#define V8_OBJECTS_TRUSTED_OBJECT_H_
7
8#include "src/objects/heap-object.h"
9
10// Has to be the last include (doesn't have include guards):
11#include "src/objects/object-macros.h"
12
13namespace v8 {
14namespace internal {
15
16#include "torque-generated/src/objects/trusted-object-tq.inc"
17
18// An object that is trusted to not have been modified in a malicious way.
19//
20// Typical examples of trusted objects are containers for bytecode or code
21// metadata, which often allow an attacker to corrupt (for example) stack
22// memory when manipulated. When the sandbox is enabled, trusted objects are
23// located outside of the sandbox (in one of the trusted heap spaces) so that
24// attackers cannot corrupt these objects and use them to escape from the
25// sandbox. When the sandbox is disabled, trusted objects are treated like any
26// other objects since in that case, many other types of objects (for example
27// ArrayBuffers) can be used to corrupt memory outside of V8's heaps as well.
28//
29// Trusted objects cannot directly be referenced from untrusted objects as this
30// would be unsafe: an attacker could corrupt any (direct) pointer to these
31// objects stored inside the sandbox. However, ExposedTrustedObject can be
32// referenced via indirect pointers, which guarantee memory-safe access.
33class TrustedObject : public HeapObject {
34 public:
35 DECL_CAST(TrustedObject)
36 DECL_VERIFIER(TrustedObject)
37
38 // Protected pointers.
39 //
40 // These are pointers for which it is guaranteed that neither the pointer-to
41 // object nor the pointer itself can be modified by an attacker. In practice,
42 // this means that they must be pointers between objects in trusted space,
43 // outside of the sandbox, where they are protected from an attacker. As
44 // such, the slot accessors for these slots only exist on TrustedObjects but
45 // not on other HeapObjects.
46 inline Tagged<TrustedObject> ReadProtectedPointerField(int offset) const;
47 inline Tagged<TrustedObject> ReadProtectedPointerField(int offset,
48 AcquireLoadTag) const;
49 inline void WriteProtectedPointerField(int offset,
50 Tagged<TrustedObject> value);
51 inline void WriteProtectedPointerField(int offset,
52 Tagged<TrustedObject> value,
53 ReleaseStoreTag);
54 inline bool IsProtectedPointerFieldCleared(int offset) const;
55 inline bool IsProtectedPointerFieldCleared(int offset, AcquireLoadTag) const;
56 inline void ClearProtectedPointerField(int offset);
57 inline void ClearProtectedPointerField(int offset, ReleaseStoreTag);
58
59 inline ProtectedPointerSlot RawProtectedPointerField(int byte_offset) const;
60
61#ifdef VERIFY_HEAP
62 inline void VerifyProtectedPointerField(Isolate* isolate, int offset);
63#endif
64
65 static constexpr int kHeaderSize = HeapObject::kHeaderSize;
66
67 OBJECT_CONSTRUCTORS(TrustedObject, HeapObject);
68};
69
70// A trusted object that can safely be referenced from untrusted objects.
71//
72// These objects live in trusted space but are "exposed" to untrusted objects
73// living inside the sandbox. They still cannot be referenced through "direct"
74// pointers (these can be corrupted by an attacker), but instead they must be
75// referenced through "indirect pointers": an index into a pointer table that
76// contains the actual pointer as well as a type tag. This mechanism then
77// guarantees memory-safe access.
78//
79// We want to have one pointer table entry per referenced object, *not* per
80// reference. As such, there must be a way to obtain an existing table entry
81// for a given (exposed) object. This base class provides that table entry in
82// the form of the 'self' indirect pointer.
83//
84// The need to inherit from this base class to make a trusted object accessible
85// means that it is not possible to expose existing utility objects such as
86// hash tables or fixed arrays. Instead, those would need to be "wrapped" by
87// another ExposedTrustedObject. This limitation is by design: if we were to
88// create such an exposed utility object, it would likely weaken the
89// type-safety mechanism of indirect pointers because indirect pointers are
90// (effectively) tagged with the target's instance type. As such, if the same
91// object type is used in different contexts, they would both use the same type
92// tag, allowing an attacker to perform a "substitution attack". As a concrete
93// example, consider the case of a trusted, exposed byte array. If such a byte
94// array is used (a) to hold some sort of bytecode for an interpreter and (b)
95// some sort of trusted metadata, then an attacker can take a trusted byte
96// array from context (a) and use it in context (b) or vice versa. This would
97// effectively result in a type confusion and likely lead to an escape from the
98// sandbox. This problem goes away if (a) and (b) each use a dedicated object
99// with a unique instance type. It is of course still possible to build new
100// utility objects on top of this class, but hopefully this comment serves to
101// document the potential pitfalls when doing so.
102class ExposedTrustedObject : public TrustedObject {
103 public:
104 // Initializes this object by creating its pointer table entry.
105 inline void init_self_indirect_pointer(IsolateForSandbox isolate);
106
107 // Returns the 'self' indirect pointer of this object.
108 // This indirect pointer references a pointer table entry (either in the
109 // trusted pointer table or the code pointer table for Code objects) through
110 // which this object can be referenced from inside the sandbox.
111 inline IndirectPointerHandle self_indirect_pointer_handle() const;
112
113 DECL_CAST(ExposedTrustedObject)
114 DECL_VERIFIER(ExposedTrustedObject)
115
116#ifdef V8_ENABLE_SANDBOX
117 // The 'self' indirect pointer is only available when the sandbox is enabled.
118 // Otherwise, these objects are referenced through direct pointers.
119#define FIELD_LIST(V) \
120 V(kSelfIndirectPointerOffset, kIndirectPointerSize) \
121 V(kUnalignedHeaderSize, OBJECT_POINTER_PADDING(kUnalignedHeaderSize)) \
122 V(kHeaderSize, 0) \
123 V(kSize, 0)
124
125 DEFINE_FIELD_OFFSET_CONSTANTS(TrustedObject::kHeaderSize, FIELD_LIST)
126#undef FIELD_LIST
127#else // V8_ENABLE_SANDBOX
128 static constexpr int kHeaderSize = TrustedObject::kHeaderSize;
129#endif // V8_ENABLE_SANDBOX
130
131 OBJECT_CONSTRUCTORS(ExposedTrustedObject, TrustedObject);
132};
133
134} // namespace internal
135} // namespace v8
136

139#endif // V8_OBJECTS_TRUSTED_OBJECT_H_
